Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Diversity and evolution of fungal endophytes in native Hawaiian plants
Award.AbstractNarration:
Inside nearly all healthy plant leaves reside a diverse community of fungi invisible to the naked eye. These cryptic symbionts, known as foliar fungal endophytes, span hundreds of millions of years of evolutionary history, are linked to plant fitness and are thought to comprise a wealth of undocumented species and biochemical compounds. Despite their ubiquity and diversity, little is known about why different fungal endophyte species are found in different plants. Hawaii's endemic and imperiled flora provides an opportunity to collect and describe a unique set of these organisms, while determining the extent to which environment, barriers to dispersal and plant evolutionary history shape these fungal symbionts' diversity and distribution across islands. PIs Amend and Perry will inventory fungal foliar endophytes from a broad selection of Hawaii's endemic plants and diverse habitats using a combination of DNA sequencing and culturing techniques.

Hawaii's fungi are almost entirely undocumented, yet are undoubtedly disappearing as quickly as Hawaii's critically endangered plants. This project will enumerate the species involved in one of the most pervasive cross-kingdom symbioses in natural and agricultural systems, while also preserving biological material for future experimentation and potential natural product discovery. Through this project, Perry and Amend will train local high school, undergraduate and graduate students in fungal taxonomy and systematics, molecular ecology and evolutionary biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Found inside the healthy leaf tissue of every plant species yet examined, foliar fungal endophytes shape plant interactions with the environment and can protect against pathogens and herbivores. Though invisible to the naked eye, endophytic fungi form ubiquitous and hyperdiverse communities spanning hundreds of millions of years of evolutionary history. It is suspected that these cryptic symbionts comprise a large portion of the estimated 93?98% of fungal species diversity that remains undocumented.In this project we completed a systematic and comprehensive biological inventory of fungal foliar endophytes of native and endemic Hawaiian plants, including more than 850 plant samples from more than 100 plant genera spread across five of the Hawaiian Islands. Nearly 500 million fungal DNA barcodes were generated to estimate the diversity and distribution of Hawaiian endophytes, and over 2100 living fungal cultures were isolated from the leaves of Hawaiian plants. These isolates are now preserved in a culture collection at California State University East Bay, and form an invaluable resource for future research and plant conservation efforts. Our results suggest that endophytes vary by environment, and are most sensitive to elevation and evapotranspiration, two factors that might enable us to predict where species might occur in other locations not sampled. Many fungi were unique to (or statistically associated with) a single island. While we found some evidence suggesting that closely related plants harbor more similar fungi, this pattern was comparatively weak, and was typically masked by other environmental variables. 

This project was a collaborative effort between investigators from the University of Hawaii at Manoa and California State University, East Bay (CSUEB). The project supported and/or provided research experience for six graduate students and five undergraduate students from CSUEB, and resulted in peer-reviewed publications, coverage in the media, and presentations at local and national meetings. The students involved in the project at CSUEB have gone on to pursue both M.Sc. and Ph.D. degrees in Biology, or have secured employment in the biotechnology sector. This project significantly advanced our understanding and documentation of fungal diversity in Hawaii and the Pacific. The data and living resources generated by this project have the potential to both advance and support plant conservation efforts in Hawaii and elsewhere.
